sentences.sentence: Alberta wants a fair deal from Canada, but can't seem to get one.
Should it build a firewall?
Stop trying?
Separate?

This is one of a series of opinion pieces adapted from the new book, "Moment of Truth: How to Think About Alberta's Future," in which some of Canada's most respected thinkers on the subject debate what the best next steps are for Alberta - and for Canada.In recent days, the authors of "Moment of Truth: How to Think About Alberta's Future," have documented how the province today is much worse off, much more vulnerable to predatory and destructive policies from Ottawa, than it was 30 years ago.
We have discussed how this predicament came about, and some of the options available to Albertans and their fellow westerners.

Now it's time to outline a new strategy for Alberta to secure its future.What follows is a brief manifesto, a short list of political actions that will increase the voice and influence of Alberta (and the West) in Ottawa.Campaign much more strategically and vigorously in central and Atlantic Canada for necessary reforms.

In particular, abandon the erroneous assumption (politically crippling when held and asserted by westerners) that the electorates of Ontario (121 federal seats) and Quebec (78 federal seats) are homogeneous, totally indifferent or opposed to the reforms that western Canadians want, and can never be won over to western positions.
This simply isn't true as any westerner who has campaigned for votes in those areas can attest.
?Note that northwest Ontario has more in common with the resource producing interests of the West than it does with Toronto and southern Ontario (it's even in a different time zone.)
Likewise, northwestern Quebec (which supported the Saguenay pipeline) is as alienated from the Montreal elites as northwestern Ontario is from Toronto.

And note that many of the recent immigrants to Central Canada are socially conservative (hold strong family and religious values) and can be appealed to and rallied to conservative and pro-West positions on that ground (as Jason Kenney proved when he was minister of citizenship and immigration).Seek to build a loose coalition of conservative-oriented premiers within the Council of the Federation (with the premiers of Alberta and Saskatchewan taking the lead), to resist further Ottawa intrusion in areas of provincial and joint jurisdiction.

?Note that every province should be in favour of pressing for a constitutional amendment (or at least a federal-provincial agreement) prohibiting the federal government from legislating, taxing, spending or treaty-making in areas of provincial jurisdiction (such as natural resource development and conservation) or joint jurisdiction (such as environmental protection) without the consent of the affected province.Challenge every federal and provincial party to develop a strong section in its party/election platform to address the need for institutional and structural reform of the federation, with the United Conservative Party and the Conservative Party of Canada leading the way by example.

Publicly chastise those who fail to do so, mainly through social media.Lever any coalition achievable through the Council of the Federation to secure support from the conservative-oriented governing provincial parties in Alberta, Saskatchewan, Manitoba, Ontario, Quebec, New Brunswick and Prince Edward Island for the CPC and the pro-western elements of its platform in the next federal election.Actively and vigorously practice national (not just regional) political "coalition building" to protect and advance western economic and political interests - on such issues as resource development, domestic free trade, unobstructed transportation corridors, etc.
- just as left-of-centre groups have successfully built powerful and influential coalitions to advance their interests.Urge the Alberta and Saskatchewan governments to create a special (royal?)
commission on the future of the West and support it vigorously.

Structure this commission and its terms of reference along the same lines as the Royal Commission on Bilingualism and Biculturalism established by Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson in 1963 - the commission that did so much to define and entrench the Quebec/ Ontario-centric conception of Confederation.

Use this western commission to define the West as a "distinct society," to propose constitutional and other reforms necessary to express this distinctiveness and attach as an appendix a draft constitution for the western provinces based on this perspective.Organize and finance constituency-based election campaigns to replace narrow provincialists in the British Columbia legislature and on the Vancouver, Victoria and Burnaby municipal councils with broadminded Canadians dedicated to making B.C.

the gateway, not the roadblock, to Canada's Asia-Pacific trade.Encourage the leadership of the CPC to adopt the "regional lieutenant system" and assist in recruiting and supporting a "strong western lieutenant" for the current leader.

Note the effectiveness of this model in the past: John A. Macdonald had George-Ãƒ&;#8240;tienne Cartier as his Quebec lieutenant; Wilfrid Laurier had Clifford Sifton and Frank Oliver in the West; Brian Mulroney had Don Mazankowski, etc.

The next western leader of the CPC needs regional lieutenants to give him greater national clout.Follow a "two-pronged approach" politically to advancing Alberta and western interests within the federation, pursuing both an increased voice for Alberta/western interests in Ottawa, and an autonomist route of more Alberta/West and less Ottawa, with the secession threat in the background.The winner of this joint endeavour?

Alberta, the West and Canada.National PostJack M. Mintz, Tom Flanagan and Ted Morton are the editors of "Moment of Truth: How to Think About Alberta's Future," now available from Sutherland House Books.Opinion: Securing Alberta's future(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/opinion-securing-albertas-future/wcm/b2efd488-4b78-4436-888d-e3ffe6c07200/)Ted Morton: Canada's Constitution is out of step with economic reality(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/ted-morton-canadas-constitution-is-out-of-step-with-economic-reality/wcm/6efafb6e-0967-4c8a-adbb-ef885c2850b6/)Donald J. Savoie: The deck is stacked against the West(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/donald-j-savoie-the-deck-is-stacked-against-the-west/wcm/ec2920e8-d477-4a9e-9ea7-0c25cb85e038/)Jack M. Mintz: The separatist impulse - in Canada and abroad(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/jack-m-mintz-the-separatist-impulse-in-canada-and-abroad/wcm/10701785-5fd9-473a-9b07-8a2425bdd0ad/)Opinion: If Alberta can't secure free trade with Canada, it will have to look south(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/opinion-if-alberta-cant-secure-free-trade-with-canada-it-will-have-to-look-south)David J. Bercuson: Securing an independent Alberta(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/david-j-bercuson-securing-an-independent-alberta)Ted Morton: The great divide between Edmonton and Ottawa(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/ted-morton-the-great-divide-between-edmonton-and-ottawa)Kelly Ogle: A 'northern corridor' to put Canada back on the map(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/kelly-ogle-a-northern-corridor-to-put-canada-back-on-the-map)Richard Albert: A constitution to call Alberta's own(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/richard-albert-a-constitution-to-call-albertas-own) !
